docs.abstract: Pres. of Uruguay sets aside neutrality rules as applied to Allies

headline.main: WAIVES NEUTRALITY RULES.; Uruguay Decides Not to Apply Them to the Allies.

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21.--The War Trade Board has prepared a comprehensive statement concerning the restrictions placed on the export of American commodities. It puts before the exporters of the country a complete index of articles on the conservation...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21.--The War Trade Board has prepared a comprehensive statement concerning the restrictions placed on the export of American commodities. It puts before the exporters of the country a complete index of articles on the conservation list and therefore practically prohibited from export, and conditions on which other commodities may be sent to the allies of America and neutral countries.
docs.abstract: new list of commodities added to embargo

headline.main: BOARD ANNOUNCES ENLARGED EMBARGO; Many Commodities Added to Conservation List and Their Export Practically Forbidden. ARTICLES TO BE LICENSED Full Revised Lists as Officially Issued--Conditions of Shipment Under New Regulations.

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Oct. 26.-- A dinner in honor of Admiral Caperton and other American naval officers was given last night by Dr. Baltasar Brun, the Foreign Minister. It was attended by President Viera and many Ministers, members of Parliament, and...
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Oct. 26.-- A dinner in honor of Admiral Caperton and other American naval officers was given last night by Dr. Baltasar Brun, the Foreign Minister. It was attended by President Viera and many Ministers, members of Parliament, and diplomats.
docs.abstract: gives dinner to Admiral Caperton and other Amer. naval officers; says Uruguay has taken its place among nations pledged to liberty and justice

headline.main: HONOR AMERICAN OFFICERS.; Uruguayan Officials Give Dinner for Caperton and Others.

docs.abstract: Roads in the South checked by German uprising as strikes spread

headline.main: German Uprising in Southern Brazil Stops Railways as Strikes Spread; Army to Act

docs.snippet: WHY isn't Argentina in the war? Why hasn't she even broken diplomatic relations with Germany because of the Lux  burg incident, which undoubtedly served to expedite the breaking of such relations by two smaller South American nations, Uruguay and...
docs.lead_paragraph: WHY isn't Argentina in the war? Why hasn't she even broken diplomatic relations with Germany because of the Lux burg incident, which undoubtedly served to expedite the breaking of such relations by two smaller South American nations, Uruguay and Peru, though they were not so directly concerned?

headline.main: ARGENTINA'S HESITANCY TO ENTER WORLD WAR; Cross-Currents of Political Feeling Explained--An Impression That United States Should Have Taken SouthAmerica Into Partnership from Beginning.

headline.main: SENDING LUXBURG HOME.; Argentine Authorities to Watch Him Closely Until He Starts.

docs.snippet: From present indications, reports Consul William Dawson from Montevideo, it is evident that the wool clip in Uruguay this year will be unusually satisfactory, both as to quality and quantity.
docs.lead_paragraph: From present indications, reports Consul William Dawson from Montevideo, it is evident that the wool clip in Uruguay this year will be unusually satisfactory, both as to quality and quantity.

headline.main: URUGUAY'S WOOL CLIP.; This Year's Said to be Not Only Large, but of Good Quality.

docs.snippet: Henry A. Uterhart, chief counsel for Mrs. Blanca De Saulles, on trial for the murder of her husband, in his opening statement at Mineola yesterday, after the prosecution had rested, reviewed the life of Mrs. De Saulles since she, at the age of 16...
docs.lead_paragraph: Henry A. Uterhart, chief counsel for Mrs. Blanca De Saulles, on trial for the murder of her husband, in his opening statement at Mineola yesterday, after the prosecution had rested, reviewed the life of Mrs. De Saulles since she, at the age of 16 years, married John Longer De Saulles, the Yale athlete, in Paris in 1911.
docs.abstract: counsel, H. A. Uterhart, opens defense; M. Ward, Major A. De Saulles, and Mrs. Caroline Degener, father and sister of slain man, testify

headline.main: HOLDS DE SAULLES DROVE WIFE MAD; Defense Says Repeated Cruelties Made Her Mind a Blankon Day of Murder.NO "UNWRITTEN LAW" PLEAMrs. De Saulles Convinced HerSon Was to be TakenAway from Her.SHE WILL TAKE THE STAND Father and Sister of Slain Man Tell of the Tragedy--Prosecution Rests. Tells of Alleged Humiliation. Defense on the Written Law. Married in Paris. Turned Down Uruguay Post. Says De Saulles Withheld Money.

docs.snippet: Before an intensely sympathetic audience, which filled the courtroom of Justice Manning at Mineola, Mrs. Blanca De Saulles yesterday told her story of the events leading up to her killing her divorced husband, John Longer De Saulles, Yale athlete and...
docs.lead_paragraph: Before an intensely sympathetic audience, which filled the courtroom of Justice Manning at Mineola, Mrs. Blanca De Saulles yesterday told her story of the events leading up to her killing her divorced husband, John Longer De Saulles, Yale athlete and politician, who died after being shot five times by her at his home, The Box, in Westbury, on Aug. 3 of this year.

headline.main: MRS. DE SAULLES TELLS STORY OF HUSBAND'S NEGLECT; Relates on the Stand the Humiliations She EnduredBefore the Murder.DOESN'T RECALL SHOOTING Letters to Her Child's NurseDescribe Her Yearningfor Happiness. WANTED ONLY A QUIET HOME Justice Waves Lawyer Aside andTells Accused to Tell Her Storyin Her Own Way. Mrs. De Saulles Takes the Stand. Smiles at Her Photograph. MRS. DE SAULLES AS WITNESS IN TRIAL She Craved Happiness. Tells of Heartaches. Toodles Writes to "Nursie." Tell Things in Your Own Way." Saw Her Baby on the Stairs. Doesn't Recall Shooting. Reviews Her Early Life. Looked Eagerly for De Saulles. MRS. DE SAULLES AS WITNESS IN TRIAL Have Stood Everything." Gave Him More Money.
